<!-- Please use this template while reporting a bug and provide as much info as possible. Not doing so may result in your bug not being addressed in a timely manner. Thanks!

If the matter is security related, please disclose it privately via https://kubernetes.io/security/
-->


**What happened**:

In some cases, a create volume request can succeed in vSphere but time out in the vSphere storage plugin. This request will be retried, but fails with `VMDK already exists` on subsequent attempts.

As a result, the PersistentVolume object never gets created, and the pod requesting it never starts. Recovery requires manual steps.

**What you expected to happen**:

Since vSphere successfully created the volume, the storage plugin should reconcile and allow the PersistentVolume to get created.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:

This is difficult to reproduce because it is caused by specific timing between vSphere and kubernetes. For testing, I added a line of code to [vdm.go][1] to inject failures after vSphere created the volume.

[1]: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/c466fd9eaf31a6a12f901369d13129f6a8853da4/staging/src/k8s.io/legacy-cloud-providers/vsphere/vclib/diskmanagers/vdm.go#L38-L78
